comment.author: 29184580@N04
comment._content:
Wasn't the Armistice 1918?

Edit:  Checked Wikipedia, the treaty of Versailles was signed June 28, 1919.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson BTW, the armistice was a shorter term agreement, which was indeed signed in 1918 -- November 11, 1918 at Compiègne, France. It's the date still celebrated annually as "Armistice Day", "Remembrance Day," and in the US as "Veterans Day." But the volume cannot have been published until 1919 because the selection uploaded to includes pictures taken in late December 1918, when Wilson traveled to England. [Afterthought: There are also pictures from April 1919 of the returning dreadnoughts. ]

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: LoC has a copy of the Harris & Ewing photograph that was probably the basis for the rotogravure. www.loc.gov/pictures/resource/cph.3f06247/
